intro: [WRONG START] Abutilon sandwicense var. Welchii, commonly known as the Koa 'Welchii' or a variant of the Koa tree, is a tropical plant native to Hawaii. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves and showy, lantern-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 10 meters in suitable conditions. It thrives in well-drained soil and requires full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. This variety is valued for its ornamental qualities and historical significance in Hawaiian culture.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon sandwicense var. welchii is primarily native to the Hawaiian Islands, specifically the island of Maui. This variant of the species is found in the coastal areas and lowland forests of Maui. It thrives in the humid, tropical climate typical of the region. The plant is adapted to the unique ecological conditions of the Hawaiian ecosystem. Due to its restricted range, it is considered a rare and endemic species.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon sandwicense var. welchii was mainly introduced to Hawaii. It was introduced as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. The plant is native to the Hawaiian Islands and has been cultivated in various parts of the region. It is commonly found in disturbed areas and along roadsides. However, it is not considered invasive and has limited ecological impact.
